title: 104_s1589
content: The "Presidential Primary Act of 1996" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The definition section clarifies key terms within the Act. The "Presidential Primary Act of 1996" defines key terms such as "election year," "national committee," "political party," and "primary." The "Presidential Primary Act of 1996" defines key terms such as "primary" as a selection of delegates to a national Presidential nominating convention, and "State committee" as the organization responsible for the day-to-day operation of a political party at the State level. The "Presidential Primary Act of 1996" defines key terms such as "primary" as a selection of delegates to a national Presidential nominating convention, and "State committee" as the organization responsible for the day-to-day operation of a political party at the State level. SEC. 3. SCHEDULE. In the first election year after the enactment of the "Presidential Primary Act of 1996," each State must hold primaries according to a schedule based on regions. Region I primaries are on the first Tuesday in March, Region II in April, Region III in May, and Region IV in June. Subsequent election cycles follow a similar schedule. In subsequent election years, each State in each region must hold its primary on the first Tuesday of the month following the month of the previous election year. Region I includes Connecticut, Delaware, District of Columbia, and Maine. Region II includes Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, and Virginia. Region III includes Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota, and Wisconsin. Region IV includes Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, and New Mexico. The national committees determine the regions of territories in the United States, including Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming. The Federal Election Commission certifies names of candidates to states for primary ballots. States must include certified names and other determined by state committees. State delegates vote at national party conventions. Each State committee must establish a procedure for delegate apportionment to the national Presidential nominating convention based on either a winner-take-all system or a proportionate representation system. The State committee establishes a delegate apportionment procedure for the national convention based on winner-take-all or proportionate representation. Candidates submit a list of proposed delegates in priority order. Delegates must vote for the State primary winner at the national convention. Delegates selected under the delegate apportionment procedure must vote for the State primary winner at the national convention, unless released by the winner. This Act applies to primaries starting from the year 2000 and each election year after.
